title: Ezekiel Chapter 15 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 15 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 15 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 15.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 15:2, what is the vine tree compared to?
options: Any tree or a branch among the trees of the forest
A river in the desert
A mountain on the plains
A flower in the garden
questions.correctAnswer: Any tree or a branch among the trees of the forest
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:2 compares the vine tree to any tree or a branch among the trees of the forest.

questions.question: What question is asked about the wood of the vine tree in Ezekiel 15:3?
options: Shall wood be taken thereof to do any work?
Is it good for building houses?
Can it be carved into statues?
Does it grow fruits?
questions.correctAnswer: Shall wood be taken thereof to do any work?
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:3 asks if wood from the vine tree can be taken to do any work or to hang vessels.

questions.question: What happens to the vine tree wood according to Ezekiel 15:4?
options: It is cast into the fire for fuel and burned
It is made into furniture
It is planted again
It is carved into idols
questions.correctAnswer: It is cast into the fire for fuel and burned
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:4 states that the vine tree wood is cast into the fire for fuel and is burned completely.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 15:5, what is said about the vine tree when it was whole?
options: It was meet for no work
It was very useful
It was the strongest wood
It was used for building
questions.correctAnswer: It was meet for no work
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:5 says that even when whole, the vine tree was not suitable for any work.

questions.question: What will God do to the inhabitants of Jerusalem according to Ezekiel 15:6?
options: Give them to the fire as the vine tree is given to the fire for fuel
Bless them with abundance
Protect them from enemies
Make them rulers over other nations
questions.correctAnswer: Give them to the fire as the vine tree is given to the fire for fuel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:6 compares the inhabitants of Jerusalem to the vine tree given to the fire for fuel.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 15:7, what will happen when God sets His face against the inhabitants?
options: They shall go out from one fire, and another fire shall devour them
They will be given peace
They will find new homes
They will prosper and multiply
questions.correctAnswer: They shall go out from one fire, and another fire shall devour them
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:7 states that when God sets His face against them, they will be devoured by fire repeatedly.

questions.question: What does God say He will make the land because of the trespass in Ezekiel 15:8?
options: Desolate
Fruitful
Blessed
Peaceful
questions.correctAnswer: Desolate
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:8 declares that God will make the land desolate because of their trespass.

questions.question: Who is addressed in Ezekiel 15:2 with the question about the vine tree?
options: Son of man
Prophet of Israel
King of Jerusalem
Priest of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Son of man
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:2 addresses the 'Son of man' with the question about the vine tree.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 15:1, who spoke to Ezekiel?
options: The word of the LORD
An angel
A prophet
A king
questions.correctAnswer: The word of the LORD
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:1 says the word of the LORD came to Ezekiel.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 15:3 asks if men will take a pin of the vine tree wood to hang a vessel on.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:3 questions if men will take a pin made from the vine tree wood to hang any vessel.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 15:5 says the vine tree is more useful after being burned in the fire.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:5 states the vine tree was not suitable for work when whole, and even less so after being burned.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 15:8, the land will be made desolate because of the inhabitants' trespass.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:8 states that the land will be made desolate due to their trespass.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ezekiel 15:4: 'Behold, it is cast into the fire for ______; the fire devoureth both the ends of it, and the midst of it is burned.'
options: fuel
wood
building
furniture
questions.correctAnswer: fuel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:4 says the vine tree is cast into the fire for fuel.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ezekiel 15:7: 'And I will set my face against them; they shall go out from one fire, and another ______ shall devour them.'
options: fire
storm
flood
enemy
questions.correctAnswer: fire
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:7 says they will go out from one fire and another fire shall devour them.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 15:6, to what is the vine tree among the trees of the forest compared?
options: Fuel for the fire
Fruitful branches
A shelter in the forest
A mighty oak
questions.correctAnswer: Fuel for the fire
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:6 states the vine tree is given to the fire for fuel, just as God will give the inhabitants of Jerusalem.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 15 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 15 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 15 teach us about the importance of being useful in our Christian walk?
options: The vine tree is good for making pins to hang vessels
The vine tree is like wood that is not fit for any work
The vine tree is the strongest wood in the forest
The vine tree is used for building houses
questions.correctAnswer: The vine tree is like wood that is not fit for any work
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:2-5 compares the vine tree to wood that is not fit for work, emphasizing that usefulness and purpose are important in the eyes of God, teaching us to be faithful and productive in our Christian life.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Ezekiel 15, what biblical truth would you share about God's discipline?
options: God’s discipline is like a fire that consumes unfruitful lives
God ignores those who are unfaithful
God always spares those who fail
God rewards those who refuse to change
questions.correctAnswer: God’s discipline is like a fire that consumes unfruitful lives
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:4-7 explains that the vine wood is cast into fire and consumed, symbolizing how God’s judgment consumes those who are unfruitful, teaching us about the seriousness of repentance and perseverance through trials.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 15 suggest about trusting in outward appearances or status in spiritual life?
options: The vine tree’s value is in its strength and beauty
Outward appearance guarantees usefulness
The vine tree is no better than other trees for useful work
The strongest trees are always the most faithful
questions.correctAnswer: The vine tree is no better than other trees for useful work
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:2 teaches that the vine tree is no better than other trees or branches for useful work, reminding us that outward appearances or status do not guarantee spiritual fruitfulness or usefulness.

questions.question: How does this passage encourage humility in our service to God and others?
options: By showing that even the vine tree is highly praised
By teaching that none of us are inherently useful without God’s purpose
By encouraging self-promotion to gain favor
By rewarding those who boast in their works
questions.correctAnswer: By teaching that none of us are inherently useful without God’s purpose
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:5 shows the vine tree was not fit for work even when whole, illustrating the need for humility and dependence on God’s purpose rather than our own abilities or achievements.

questions.question: What practical lesson about perseverance can be drawn from Ezekiel 15's description of the vine wood in the fire?
options: All trials are meant to destroy us completely
God allows believers to be refined like wood in fire
Those unfruitful will be consumed by judgment
Fire makes the vine wood stronger
questions.correctAnswer: Those unfruitful will be consumed by judgment
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:4-7 portrays unfruitful wood being consumed by fire, symbolizing how those who fail to bear fruit face judgment, teaching perseverance in faith and obedience to avoid spiritual destruction.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with feeling useless in their service. What does Ezekiel 15 teach about usefulness and purpose?
options: Only the strongest believers serve God
God uses everyone who is faithful and fruitful
The vine tree is the most useful for work
God does not require fruitfulness
questions.correctAnswer: God uses everyone who is faithful and fruitful
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:2-5 emphasizes that the vine tree is not fit for work because it is unfruitful, which teaches that faithfulness and fruitfulness are key to being useful in God's service.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 15 illustrate the consequences of sin for the community of believers?
options: Sin leads to restoration and blessing
Sin causes God to set His face against the people and bring destruction
Sin is ignored by God in times of trouble
Sin is an opportunity for greater wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Sin causes God to set His face against the people and bring destruction
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:6-8 shows that God sets His face against the inhabitants of Jerusalem because of their trespass, leading to desolation, teaching the serious communal consequences of sin.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 15, the vine wood is highly valued for making pins to hang vessels.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:3 questions if wood from the vine tree is used to make pins to hang vessels, implying it is not suitable for such purposes, showing it is not highly valued.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 15 teaches that God’s judgment can be compared to fire consuming useless wood.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:4-7 clearly compares God's judgment on unfruitful people to fire consuming wood that is unfit for work, illustrating the consuming nature of divine judgment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 15 compares the inhabitants of Jerusalem to _____, which God has given to the fire for fuel.
options: the vine tree among the trees of the forest
a strong oak tree in the forest
a fruitful olive tree
a cedar in Lebanon
questions.correctAnswer: the vine tree among the trees of the forest
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:6 explicitly states that the inhabitants of Jerusalem are like the vine tree among the trees of the forest given to the fire for fuel, illustrating their impending judgment.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 15 guide us in understanding God's seriousness about holiness and obedience?
options: God tolerates all disobedience without consequence
God’s judgment is like fire consuming the useless wood
God rewards disobedience with blessings
God is indifferent to the fruitfulness of His people
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgment is like fire consuming the useless wood
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:4-7 uses the metaphor of fire consuming vine wood to show God’s serious judgment against disobedience and unfruitfulness, underscoring the call to holiness.

questions.question: What does the fire in Ezekiel 15 symbolize in the context of Christian life and trials?
options: A refining process for believers
A destructive judgment on unfruitfulness
A source of warmth and comfort
A symbol of prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: A destructive judgment on unfruitfulness
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:4-7 describes the fire as consuming both ends and the midst of the vine wood, symbolizing God's destructive judgment on those who are unfruitful in faith and obedience.

questions.question: What practical advice about integrity and fruitfulness can be drawn from the metaphor of the vine tree in Ezekiel 15?
options: Integrity is unimportant if you appear fruitful
Fruitfulness and integrity are essential to avoid God’s judgment
Only outward success matters in Christian life
One can avoid consequences despite unfruitfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Fruitfulness and integrity are essential to avoid God’s judgment
questions.explanation: The chapter teaches through the vine wood metaphor (Ezekiel 15:2-7) that fruitfulness and integrity in life and service are necessary to be useful and to avoid God’s consuming judgment.

questions.question: How does this passage teach us about God’s attitude toward sin in a community?
options: God blesses communities regardless of sin
God sets His face against the community that trespasses
God is unaware of community sin
God only judges individuals, not communities
questions.correctAnswer: God sets His face against the community that trespasses
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:7-8 states that God sets His face against the inhabitants because of their trespass and makes the land desolate, showing His serious stance against communal sin.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 15 imply about the role of repentance and obedience in avoiding God’s judgment?
options: Repentance and obedience can prevent being consumed like unfruitful wood
God’s judgment is unavoidable regardless of behavior
Obedience has no impact on God’s action
Only outward appearances matter to God
questions.correctAnswer: Repentance and obedience can prevent being consumed like unfruitful wood
questions.explanation: The metaphor of the vine wood being consumed by fire (Ezekiel 15:4-7) implies that repentance and obedience can help avoid God’s consuming judgment, encouraging faithful perseverance.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 15 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 15.

questions.question: What metaphor does Ezekiel use in chapter 15 to describe the inhabitants of Jerusalem?
options: The vine tree cast into the fire
The olive tree bearing fruit
The cedar tree on the mountain
The fig tree withered by drought
questions.correctAnswer: The vine tree cast into the fire
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:6 explicitly compares the inhabitants of Jerusalem to a vine tree given to the fire for fuel, symbolizing judgment and destruction.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 15, why is the vine tree considered useless for work or making a pin?
options: Because it is soft and easily broken
Because it was never meant for structural use
Because its wood is too light
Because it is too bitter to use
questions.correctAnswer: Because it was never meant for structural use
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:3 and 15:5 indicate that the vine tree's wood is not fit for any work or making pins, emphasizing its uselessness even before being burned.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 15, what is the fate of the vine tree after it is cast into the fire?
options: It is consumed entirely with both ends and midst burned
It produces new branches
It turns into fertile ash
It is preserved for woodwork
questions.correctAnswer: It is consumed entirely with both ends and midst burned
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:4 states the fire devours both ends and the midst of the vine tree, making it unfit for any work.

questions.question: What does God's setting His face against the inhabitants of Jerusalem symbolize in Ezekiel 15?
options: His judgment and wrath
His protection and favor
His indifference
His mourning
questions.correctAnswer: His judgment and wrath
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:7 describes God setting His face against Jerusalem's inhabitants, indicating divine judgment and punishment.

questions.question: Which phrase from Ezekiel 15 indicates a repeated or continuous punishment upon the inhabitants of Jerusalem?
options: "They shall go out from one fire, and another fire shall devour them"
"The land shall blossom as the rose"
"They shall be gathered like sheaves in the harvest"
"Their foes shall be scattered like chaff"
questions.correctAnswer: "They shall go out from one fire, and another fire shall devour them"
questions.explanation: This phrase in Ezekiel 15:7 highlights the ongoing and relentless nature of the judgment on Jerusalem.

questions.question: What is the significance of calling the vine tree 'meet for no work' even when it was whole, in Ezekiel 15?
options: It indicates inherent uselessness pointing to Israel's spiritual failure
It suggests the vine was intended only for fruit-bearing
It implies the wood was sacred and untouchable
It means the tree was too young to use
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates inherent uselessness pointing to Israel's spiritual failure
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:5 uses the vine tree's uselessness to symbolize the spiritual state of Jerusalem’s inhabitants, unfit for any productive purpose.

questions.question: How does the imagery of the vine tree in Ezekiel 15 connect to Israel's identity in other biblical texts?
options: Israel is often portrayed as a vine in both Psalms and Isaiah
Israel is depicted as a cedar in all prophetic books
Israel is symbolized by a fig tree exclusively in the New Testament
Israel is never associated with trees outside Ezekiel
questions.correctAnswer: Israel is often portrayed as a vine in both Psalms and Isaiah
questions.explanation: The vine as a symbol for Israel appears frequently, e.g., Psalm 80:8-16 and Isaiah 5:1-7, reflecting Israel’s relationship with God, which Ezekiel 15 echoes.

questions.question: True or False: In Ezekiel 15, the burning of the vine tree is used to foreshadow the destruction of Jerusalem by foreign armies.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:6-8 uses the burning vine tree as a typological foreshadowing of Jerusalem's destruction due to their trespass and sin.

questions.question: What does the term 'Son of man' in Ezekiel 15:2 emphasize about the prophet Ezekiel's role?
options: His humanity and role as God's messenger
His divine nature
His priestly authority
His royal lineage
questions.correctAnswer: His humanity and role as God's messenger
questions.explanation: The phrase 'Son of man' underscores Ezekiel’s human status while highlighting his prophetic duty to relay God's message, as seen in Ezekiel 15:2.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in Ezekiel 15 through the comparison of the vine tree to Jerusalem's inhabitants?
options: Extended metaphor
Chiasm
Alliteration
Parable
questions.correctAnswer: Extended metaphor
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15 employs an extended metaphor, comparing the vine tree to Jerusalem’s people to illustrate their uselessness and impending judgment (Ezekiel 15:2-6).

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'I will make the land desolate' in Ezekiel 15:8 within the historical context of the Babylonian exile?
options: It reflects the impending devastation of Judah and Jerusalem by Babylon
It promises restoration and rebuilding
It refers to a symbolic spiritual renewal
It pertains to a drought affecting agriculture
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the impending devastation of Judah and Jerusalem by Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:8 pronounces desolation as a consequence of Israel’s trespass, reflecting the historical reality of Babylonian conquest and exile.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 15:4, the phrase 'the fire devoureth both the ends of it, and the midst of it is burned' is an example of what kind of Hebrew poetic technique?
options: Inclusio (enclosing structure)
Parallelism
Simile
Chiasm
questions.correctAnswer: Inclusio (enclosing structure)
questions.explanation: The description of the fire consuming both ends and the midst creates an inclusio, framing total destruction in Ezekiel 15:4.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 15 emphasize the theme of divine judgment in relation to covenant unfaithfulness?
options: By comparing Jerusalem to a worthless vine burned as fuel
By promising immediate blessings and prosperity
By recounting Israel's victories in battle
By ignoring the people's sins
questions.correctAnswer: By comparing Jerusalem to a worthless vine burned as fuel
questions.explanation: The chapter uses the metaphor of a vine tree burned as fuel to highlight the consequences of Israel's covenant breach and ensuing divine judgment (Ezekiel 15:6-8).

questions.question: Which aspect of ancient Near Eastern culture is reflected in Ezekiel 15’s use of fire and wood imagery?
options: Use of wood as fuel for fire symbolizing destruction
Sacred trees worshipped as gods
Wood as a symbol of fertility and blessing
Fire as a symbol of harvest
questions.correctAnswer: Use of wood as fuel for fire symbolizing destruction
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, wood was primarily used as fuel, and fire symbolized purifying destruction, as reflected in Ezekiel 15’s imagery (Ezekiel 15:4-6).

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 15 suggests that the wood of the vine tree has potential value once it has been burned.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:5 emphasizes that the vine wood was unfit for work even when whole and is even less useful after being burned, symbolizing utter worthlessness.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 15 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 15 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What question does God ask Ezekiel regarding the vine tree in Ezekiel 15?
options: What is the vine tree more than any tree, or than a branch which is among the trees of the forest?
Why do men plant the vine tree among other trees?
Is the vine tree better for fruit than any other tree?
Can the vine tree be used for building a house?
questions.correctAnswer: What is the vine tree more than any tree, or than a branch which is among the trees of the forest?
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:2 records God asking what the vine tree is more than any other tree or branch among the trees of the forest, highlighting the vine's comparative value or lack thereof.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 15, for what practical use is the wood of the vine tree NOT suitable?
options: To do any work or to make a pin to hang a vessel
To bear fruit for eating
To be planted in the forest
To make a crown for a king
questions.correctAnswer: To do any work or to make a pin to hang a vessel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:3 states that the wood of the vine tree is not taken to do any work nor to make a pin to hang any vessel, demonstrating its lack of usefulness as timber.

questions.question: What happens to the vine tree wood when it is cast into the fire, according to Ezekiel 15?
options: The fire devours both the ends and the midst of it
It burns slowly and is preserved
It melts and becomes liquid
It produces smoke but does not burn
questions.correctAnswer: The fire devours both the ends and the midst of it
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:4 explains that when the vine tree wood is cast into the fire, the fire devours both its ends and the middle, indicating complete destruction.

questions.question: Ezekiel 15 compares the vine tree to what judgment on the inhabitants of Jerusalem?
options: As the vine tree given to the fire for fuel, so will the inhabitants be given to destruction
As the vine tree bears good fruit, so will Jerusalem be blessed
As the vine tree grows among other trees, so will Jerusalem prosper
As the vine tree is pruned, so will Jerusalem be refined
questions.correctAnswer: As the vine tree given to the fire for fuel, so will the inhabitants be given to destruction
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:6 uses the analogy of the vine tree given to the fire to illustrate how God will give the inhabitants of Jerusalem to destruction because of their sins.

questions.question: What does God say He will do when He 'sets His face against' the inhabitants of Jerusalem?
options: They shall go out from one fire to another fire
He will bless them with abundance
He will protect them from their enemies
He will restore their land and people
questions.correctAnswer: They shall go out from one fire to another fire
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:7 describes God setting His face against Jerusalem's inhabitants so that they will go from one fire to another, symbolizing ongoing judgment and punishment.

questions.question: What is the ultimate consequence for the land because of the inhabitants' trespass, as stated in Ezekiel 15?
options: The land will be made desolate
The land will yield abundant crops
The land will be a place of refuge
The land will be given to the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: The land will be made desolate
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:8 declares that the land will be made desolate because the inhabitants committed a trespass, signifying the severe consequences of sin.

questions.question: What theological truth about human sin and judgment is illustrated by the analogy of the vine tree in Ezekiel 15?
options: Unfruitful and useless people face divine judgment like worthless wood cast into fire
All trees, including the vine, are equally valuable to God
God does not judge individuals for their unfruitfulness
The vine tree represents God's mercy and salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Unfruitful and useless people face divine judgment like worthless wood cast into fire
questions.explanation: The analogy in Ezekiel 15:2-6 shows that just as the vine tree wood is useless and burned, so unfruitful people who do not serve God's purpose will face judgment, consistent with passages like John 15:6 and Hebrews 6:7-8.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 15 reveal an attribute of God related to justice?
options: God sets His face against sin and punishes unfaithfulness
God overlooks all sins and shows only mercy
God is indifferent to human actions
God rewards sin to teach lessons
questions.correctAnswer: God sets His face against sin and punishes unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:7 shows God's justice in setting His face against the sinful inhabitants, demonstrating His righteous opposition to sin, as similarly taught in Romans 1:18 and Nahum 1:2.

questions.question: Which Christological theme can be connected to the imagery of the vine in Ezekiel 15?
options: The necessity of abiding in Christ, the true Vine, to bear fruit and avoid judgment
Christ as a mighty oak tree that shelters all
Jesus as the root that must be cut down
The vine representing the Law that condemns
questions.correctAnswer: The necessity of abiding in Christ, the true Vine, to bear fruit and avoid judgment
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15's vine imagery contrasts useless wood with the true Vine, Christ, who commands believers to abide in Him to bear fruit (John 15:1-6), warning of judgment for unfruitfulness.

questions.question: What does the fire that devours the vine wood symbolize in an eschatological context?
options: The final judgment and destruction of the unrepentant
A purifying fire of sanctification
The Holy Spirit's refining work
The warmth of God's love
questions.correctAnswer: The final judgment and destruction of the unrepentant
questions.explanation: The devouring fire in Ezekiel 15:4-7 symbolizes God's judgment, akin to the eternal fire described in Matthew 25:41 and Revelation 20:14 as the fate of the unrepentant.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 15 demonstrate the seriousness of sin against God?
options: By showing that sin leads to desolation and divine rejection
By suggesting sin is easily forgiven without consequences
By portraying sin as a minor offense
By ignoring the consequences of sin
questions.correctAnswer: By showing that sin leads to desolation and divine rejection
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:8 states the land will be desolate because of trespass, illustrating that sin provokes God's judgment and results in ruin, consistent with Isaiah 59:2 and Romans 6:23.

questions.question: In the context of Ezekiel 15, what does the phrase 'I will set my face against them' imply about God's nature?
options: God's determined judgment and opposition to sin
God's willingness to ignore wrongdoing
God's indifference to human behavior
God's unconditional acceptance of all
questions.correctAnswer: God's determined judgment and opposition to sin
questions.explanation: 'Setting His face' in Ezekiel 15:7 indicates God's resolute decision to judge and oppose sin, reflecting His holiness and justice as seen in Exodus 33:20 and Ezekiel 1:8.

questions.question: What does the uselessness of the vine wood teach about human usefulness in God's kingdom?
options: That unproductive lives bear no spiritual fruit and face judgment
That all humans are equally useful regardless of their actions
That external appearances determine usefulness
That usefulness is based on worldly success
questions.correctAnswer: That unproductive lives bear no spiritual fruit and face judgment
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:5 highlights the vine's wood was never fit for work, symbolizing that those who do not bear spiritual fruit are judged, paralleling Jesus' teaching in Matthew 7:19 and Luke 13:6-9.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 15 contribute to biblical theology concerning God's covenant relationship with Israel?
options: It warns that breaking the covenant leads to judgment and desolation
It promises unconditional blessings regardless of behavior
It denies any consequences for covenant unfaithfulness
It replaces Israel's covenant with a new one immediately
questions.correctAnswer: It warns that breaking the covenant leads to judgment and desolation
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15:6-8 reflects the covenantal principle that Israel's disobedience results in judgment and land desolation, consistent with Deuteronomy 28 and Jeremiah 11:3.

questions.question: What apologetic insight does Ezekiel 15 provide regarding God's justice in punishing sin?
options: God's judgment is righteous and necessary to uphold holiness
God is unjust in punishing the innocent
God punishes arbitrarily without cause
God's justice is secondary to mercy
questions.correctAnswer: God's judgment is righteous and necessary to uphold holiness
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 15 shows that God's judgment against sin is just and necessary to maintain holiness, supporting apologetic affirmations found in Psalm 89:14 and Romans 3:25-26.
